awd_titl_txt: IRES:International Research Experience in Nanotechnology in Japan 2015
awd_abstract_narration:
Nanotechnology is a world-wide research enterprise. It is essential for young researchers to learn to excel in this environment. While science is universal, the process by which peers do science by communicating with each other is not. In this context, communication is about much more than language. Language is the easy part as almost all scientists speak English.  But issues of gender roles, seniority, directness, and formality all differ, to mention just a few.  This International Research Experience for Students award supports five outstanding U.S. undergraduate students per year for three years to conduct nanotechnology research at the National Institute of Materials Science in Japan. The students selected for this program are promising young scientists with an interest in nanotechnology who have already successfully completed one significant domestic nanotechnology training experience through the National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network/National Nanotechnology Coordination Infrastructure (NNIN/NNCI) Research Experience for Undergraduates program. The IRES program enhances participating students? scientific skills with a more advanced research project while simultaneously building their awareness of international research culture. This program uses anew qualitative assessment instrument for measuring and increasing the impact of the research experience on global research awareness.
The National Institute of Materials Science (NIMS) is a leading inter
national research facility with a broad program in nanotechnology. The research component part of the program concentrates on two subfields of nanotechnology where considerable student interest is evident: energy and nanobiotechnology. The five selected students will participate in an individual focused research project under the supervision of a senior NIMS researcher. In the energy arena, projects may include real time monitoring of energy conversion processes, novel nano-photocatalytic materials for solar fuel production, and development of viable thermoelectric materials. Nanobiotechnology projects may include smart materials for biomedical applications, nanobiointerfaces for analyzing cellular function, nanostructured scaffolds for cell function manipulation, and immune system regulation through a nanoparticle mediated DNA drug delivery mechanism.

This award is jointly funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering, Directorate for Engineering Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems and Nanoscale Science and Engineering Program.

por.por_cntn:
This award under the International Research Experience for Students program supported 18 students (3 cohorts of 6 students) for a nanotechnology focused summer research experience at the National Institute of Materials Science in Tsukuba, Japan.

Engineering and scientific research in the 20th century is a global enterprise. To be effective contributors in this environment, young scientists need to learn to be effective global scientists. While science itself is universal, the manner in which it is conducted and communicated is not. This is a learned behavior but one which most young US scientists are not exposed to.  In contrast, it is quite normal for young foreign scientists to come to the United States early in their careers.  This is the same challenge met by international corporations who take considerable pain to develop ?cultural intelligence? in their managers and scientists.

This project addressed the need to develop Globally Aware Scientists who can function effectively in the 21st century global research enterprise. Participants were selected from experienced undergraduate researchers with sufficient knowledge and maturity to benefit from the experience.

This is the third IRES award for this program which has been conducted with various sources of funding since 2008, with a total of 75 participants.

The students in this program conducted research on a variety of nanotechnology topics at the National Institute for Materials Science in Tsukuba, Japan, under the direction of a Senior NIMS staff scientist, working in a culturally diverse research team in a completely foreign culture. Some of the projects involved hard electronic materials, including materials for improved thermoelectric energy conversion and for improved solar cells. In the area of nanobiotechnology, projects involved the interaction of cells with nanostructured surfaces and nanoparticles. The research projects were part of the normal research portfolio of the National Institute for Materials Science, scaled so that the student could make a significant contribution within the 10 week research period. The technical merit of their work is demonstrated by the publications that many of the participants contributed to during their short tenure in Japan. Publications take some time to develop, and some of this programs outcomes are still in development.  Overall, however, the 75 former participants have been contributing authors on over 30 publications.

Ultimately, this is a human resources program that falls most closely within the Broader Impacts criteria. And it has been most effective in that regard. Assessments of each participant conducted before and after the program showed significant improvement of cultural intelligence, the ability and interest in cross cultural communication.
